Key Arguments: The legislation represents a regressive move towards censorship and control of public discussion.
Addressing root causes like inequality, poverty, and lack of education is more effective than censorship.
The Bill could entrench polarization, distrust, extremism, and violence in society.
It poses a threat to freedom of speech and could have anti-competitive effects.
The Bill is overly broad and applies extraterritorially, affecting even foreign website owners.
It conflicts with the News Media Bargaining Code and could harm minorities.
The Bill is unconstitutional and disempowers ordinary people.
It could destroy democracy by limiting access to diverse political viewpoints.
The Bill could lead to state media dominance and is inequitable.
It threatens freedom of faith and religious freedom.
Notable Quotes: Banning dissident opinions and beliefs, however repugnant we find them, does not make them go away: rather they go underground and become more virulent, extreme and disconnected from any sense of shared reality.
Aggressive Enforcement Encourages the Very Thing You Wish to Eliminate.
It violates the constitution's implied freedom of political communication, and amounts to an unconstitutional abdication of the legislative power of Parliament.

Ordinary people will wonder what the point of trying to be involved in public conversation is when you know your viewpoint might be arbitrarily silenced or categorised as misinformation or disinformation.
